newsitem.title: USA: Washington Rep. Linda Smith bids for Senate seat.
newsitem.headline: Washington Rep. Linda Smith bids for Senate seat.

text.p: U.S. Representative Linda Smith, a Christian conservative swept into office in the 1994 Republican landslide, said Monday she would seek the Senate seat held by Washington Democrat Patty Murray.

Smith, who survived a tough Democratic challenge last year to narrowly win re-election to a second term, said she was driven by her belief in the need for campaign finance reform, lower taxes and less government interference.
"We live at a time when government is trying to control more and more of our lives, and special interests are controlling more and more of government," she said. "I want to change that."

In announcing her bid 18 months before the general election, Smith said she would forgo traditional campaign finance methods and refuse to hold fund-raising events in Washington, D.C., or accept contributions from political action committees.
She also said she would not rely on "soft money" donated to the Republican Party and targeted for her race.
Smith, 46, of the southwestern Washington town of Hazel Dell, served in the state legislature for a decade before being elected in a write-in campaign.
Murray, 46, was a self-described "mom in tennis shoes" and one-term state senator from the Seattle area when she rode into office on President Clinton's coattails in 1992.
